My decision-making process was based solely on how much of the hurricane was hitting the oil rig.  If there were fewer lines (stemming from the origin of the hurricane) that were on or around the rig, I decided that the diameter of the hurricane was smaller due to how little of an impact it would seemingly have on the rig.  If the rig was dead in the middle of the torrential blast, I decided that the hurricane would retain a similar size, which would make less of a drastic change in the size of the diameter once it reached the oil rig.
I estimated the length, and the distance that seemed the most appropriate  was chosen as the diameter.

Strategy: I know hardly anything about hurricanes, and I felt the instructions were a little unclear. Were we supposed to assume the hurricane would grow or shrink? Or was this more a test of how well we could visualize size comparisons shown by our selection of the circle that most closely matching the hurricane size shown at the point before it hit the oil rig. I had no idea, and I just went with choosing similarly sized circles.
I figured that the further away the dot the larger the hurricane will be when it reaches that point.

If the red dot were further away and still in close proximity with the dark lines coming from the hurricane, I would assume that it became very large. If the red dot was further away from the dark lines, it would still become larger, but not as large as if it were very close to the dark lines. The diameter was always at least a little bit larger than it first began.

Initially, I looked at the position and number of the streaks stemming from the center and used how far they branched off as an indicator of the hurricane's size. Additionally, I figured that the hurricane would continue to grow, and I looked at the size of the initial storm to determine its size when it reached the rig. For most of the survey I assumed that the storm would grow a few circle sizes as it progressed, so if the storm started at an F sized circle I would usually assume it progressed to an H. After awhile, it seemed to me that the red dot on the map coordinated with the red dot on the chart below, and for a few of the slidesI used that as a reference, though it wasn't effective after those few.

At first I thought the blue lines represented the likelihood of the hurricane taking that course. Then I changed my mind to each line. If the hurricane were to travel along that line where would it end thus allowing you to calculate it's size at a particular point.
The blues lines showed where the hurricane was going, but I based the size on how dense those lines were around the oil rig. The more dense the lines are, the bigger the hurricane will be.

I looked at how big the beginning circle was and how thick the lines were where the red dot was placed. The bigger the circle the bigger I assumed the hurricane was at the red dot. Also, the thinner the strings the smaller I assumed the hurricane was.

Well I just assumed that the farther away the red dot, and the farther the hurricane has to travel the smaller the hurricane would get. So, if the hurricane already started out really far it would probably be even smaller when it reached the red dot, so I usually went a size or two down from what the original diameter of the hurricane was.
I just looked at the red dot.
I have no idea how to predict hurricane diameters, so I assumed that it would become larger as it became closer to the red dot and the diameter size got smaller if there were fewer blue lines.
I took the distance the red dot had to travel and the intensity of the color and amount of lines into consideration. the further away from the lines and color the less sever I thought it would be.

The larger the amount of water between the hurricane apex and the red dot indicates that the hurricane would get larger. I took the blue lines to mean the path that the hurricane was most likely to take. If the apex spent a longer time over the water(because the red dot was further away) then I assumed that the hurricane would then get larger.
Using the diameter measurments, I just gauged what diameter would fit the visual based on the area of red dot and the projection of the hurricane pathway.
